status_message:
The Denver Post introduces a new series about being transgender in Colorado. In Truegender, you'll meet Elsa, a 9-year-old from Boulder, who insisted as soon as she could speak that she was a girl, even though she was assigned male at birth. After family counseling last year, Elsa's parents let her choose her own name and live as a girl. 

Learn more about her journey here: dpo.st/elsa, or in the Sunday Denver Post.

Before he died in September at age 88, Gerard Cafesjian amassed a huge collection of art, jewelry and gems. Much of the fine art now is housed in the Cafesjian Center for the Arts in Armenia, and more than 900 pieces of jewelry were auctioned in Chicago in April, a collection worth $1.8 million . But his huge collection of lapidary art, minerals and gems — valued at at least $1 million — is now in Denver, being prepared for sale in September by Leslie Hindman Auctioneers.

status_message:
Fred Glover, aged 88, a veteran of the 9th Para Battalion watches a parachute jump just outside Rainville during D-Day 70 Commemorations on June 5, 2014 in Ranville, France. Friday 6th June is the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings, which saw 156,000 troops from the allied  countries — including the United Kingdom and the United States — join forces to launch an audacious attack on the beaches of Normandy, these assaults are credited with the eventual defeat of Nazi Germany. A series of events commemorating the 70th anniversary are planned for the week with many heads of state traveling to the famous beaches to pay their respects to those who lost their lives. 

MORE PHOTOS: D-Day commemorations: http://dpo.st/1rOVwwH

(Photo by Chris Jackson/Getty Images)

A LOSS THAT HURTS

An overtime goal cut the Avs' series lead over the Wild in half Monday night. But, coach Patrick Roy said the play of the game was Matt Cooke's knee-on-knee hit on Colorado's best offensive defenseman, Tyson Barrie, causing an injury will keep him out at least a month. Roy says "now we believe the league will make the right call."

Do you think Cooke should be suspended for the hit, and if so, for how long?

FRONT PAGE: Until last week, few people knew William Davidon masterminded the 1971 burglary of a Pennsylvania FBI office that revealed massive surveillance of U.S. citizens on American soil. The story remained private until Betty Medsger's book, "The Burglary: The Discovery of J. Edgar Hoover's Secret FBI," hit stores. Now Davidon's daughter, Sarah Davidon, on the faculty of the University of Colorado Medical School, explains what it was like growing up under the close eye of FBI and how she sees history repeating itself.

FULL STORY: http://dpo.st/1hqvOWL

status_message:
Black children make up 14 percent of the student population at DPS, compared with only 4 percent of teachers, according to the latest information available from the state. The gap is wider for Latinos. status_message:
To the world, Alex Sullivan was a gentle bear of a man who died in a movie theater on his 27th birthday.

To me and my family, he was something else — a friend. He was the newborn at my wedding, the smiling 3-year-old petting my dog, the 10-year-old hockey star whacking me in the shins as we played in the street, the polite teenager, the newlywed whose hug took my breath away. - Kevin Vaughan, The Denver Post
link_name: Aurora theater shooting: Alex Sullivan's life is framed in touching memories - The Denver Post

status_message: The Steelers defeated the Broncos tonight on "Monday Night Football" 28-10, to give the team a 6-2 record for the season. http://bit.ly/1r1Hqx
link_name: Steelers stop Broncos 28-10 on "Monday Night Football" - The Denver Post

status_message: Steelers waste no time. Score is now 14-10 Steelers after a short Roethlisberger pass to Hines Ward.

TOUCHDOWN, DENVER! No. 56 Robert Ayers scores a touchdown off a 54-yard fumble recovery, giving the Broncos the lead, 10-7, with 11:09 left in the third. It's the longest fumble recovery for a TD by a rookie in Bronco history.
Halftime, Broncos fans. Sort of a dull game so far, don't you think? The Steelers still lead the Broncos 7-3, but the team is known for its second-half turnarounds... Can they do it?

Minutes into the the second quarter, and the Steelers are leading the Broncos 7-3. Lots of terrible towels waving from all of the Pittsburgh fans filling this place. Here are five things to watch during the game: http://bit.ly/1r1Hqx
link_name: Broncos battle Steelers on "Monday Night Football" - The Denver Post

status_message: Smash-and-grab auto theft has increased 34 percent over last year in Denver, with 5,610 cases from January through September. To avoid it, don't leave anything of reasonably high value openly visible in your car. Anyone have a story? http://bit.ly/1R6kEy

Balloon boy event was a hoax, sheriff says. Larimer County Sheriff Jim Alderden said Richard and Mayumi Heene "put on a very good show for us, and we bought it." http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13589767
link_name: Larimer sheriff: Balloon event a hoax; charges recommended - The Denver Post

status_message: UPDATE: Sherriff did not give specifics, but he said the charges would likely be a Class 3 misdemeanor. False reporting is a Class 3 misdemeanor. News conference is set for 11 a.m. Sunday. http://bit.ly/31pxo9
BREAKING NEWS: The Larimer County Sheriff's Office is drawing up search warrants and preparing charges against Richard Heene and the "balloon boy" family. http://bit.ly/31pxo9
link_name: Balloon family to face charges - The Denver Post

Today's most-popular article among Colorado readers ... wait for it ... Balloon boy case referred to child-protection workers.

status_message:
Colorado companies have created more
jobs through federal contracts funded with stimulus dollars than
companies in every other state, according to the first batch of
Recovery Act data. 


While the number — 4,695 jobs created or saved — may sound
encouraging for Colorado, it also is misleading in terms of economic
impact.
http://www.denverpost.com/frontpage/ci_13573130
link_name: Colorado reported as having most Recovery Act jobs - The Denver Post

status_message: Hey Facebookers, a question: Are you sick of our Balloon Boy news updates?

Last post tonight for the story about the 6-year-old Colorado boy believed stuck in a balloon. Was it a publicity stunt? In a CNN Wolf Blitzer interview, the boy, Falcon, said "we did this for the show." Blitzer's follow-up: http://tinyurl.com/yjubz6j
link_name: "Balloon Boy" Falcon Henne Admits: "We Did This For The Show"

status_message: UPDATE: Reports are saying that Falcon Heene is at home and is fine.
Breaking: The 6-year-old has been found alive.

BALLOON
UPDATE: Search is widening for a 6-year-old Fort Collins boy who was
thought to be in a "homemade flying saucer" when it went up. Police
are reporting that people saw an object fall from the balloon. and search crews are continuing efforts. http://bit.ly/1MqLM2
link_name: Fort Collins boy in loose aircraft - The Denver Post

status_message: UPDATE: Authorities are searching for the boy in two Colorado locations, using ATVs, police say. The Associated Press is reporting, citing a sheriff's official, that the boy climbed into a box attached to the balloon, but the basket was not found at the crash site.
UPDATE: Richard Heene, the boy's father, is a weather chaser. We profiled him in 2007.
link_name: 2007 Profile: Boy's father a weather chaser - The Denver Post

status_message: UPDATE: Authorities say they will track back on the balloon's flight path looking for anything indicating the whereabouts of the boy.
There's no update on where the boy is.
BREAKING NEWS: Police are saying that the balloon is empty. http://bit.ly/1MqLM2
link_name: Fort Collins boy in loose aircraft - The Denver Post

status_message: URGENT: The balloon is down. Police are not approaching because of fears of an electrical charge.

Balloon moving between 35-50 mph and hovering near 1,000 feet, police are saying. The Associated Press is reporting, citing a National Guard official, that helicopters may attempt to hoist a recuer down to the balloon to reach the boy. The Denver Post has not confirmed.

The Associated Press is now reporting that the Colorado National Guard is preparing to launch a helicopter to rescue the 6-year-old boy in the helium balloon. The Denver Post's latest report has the boy near Hudson and Keenesburg, Colo., on this map: http://bit.ly/3Kq0Ql
UPDATE: Most recent report from The Denver Post newsroom scanners: the 6-year-old in the helium balloon is 9,000 feet above the ground. http://bit.ly/1MqLM2
link_name: Fort Collins boy in loose aircraft - The Denver Post

status_message: UPDATE: Police are saying the balloon is at 2,000-3,000 feet of elevation and heading south, appears to be heading higher.
URGENT: If you see the helium ballon, now described as a "homemade flying saucer," text The Denver Post  breaking news team at 720-663-9316.
BREAKING NEWS: Rescuers are tracking and chasing a "homemade flying saucer" that is in flight with a 6-year-old, by himself, on board. http://bit.ly/1MqLM2
link_name: Fort Collins boy in loose aircraft - The Denver Post

status_message: Oh my goodness! Officials in Larimer County are actively searching for a child who literally floated away from his family's home on an experimental aircraft. http://bit.ly/1Zf39b

status_message: Most news about K-12 education in Colorado is a downer — 49th in funding, urban graduation rates less than 50 percent and achievement gaps between whites and minorities. But students do fairly well at math compared to the rest of the nation: http://bit.ly/4GnpEf

"We strap down the Dumpster lid at night so (the bears) can't lift it up. But (they) have learned if they climb on top, they're heavy enough to crush the plastic lid and fall through." — Katharine DeLoach, manager of Bailey's hot dog stand: http://bit.ly/3kGhr4
